verse.name: v1
verse.lines: Well, I am a little beggarman an' beggin' I have been Threescore years and more in this little Isle of Green I'm known from the Liffey way down to Killaloe And the name that I'm known by is Old Johnny Dhu

verse.name: c1
verse.lines: Of all the trades an' callin's, sure, beggin' is the best For when a man is weary, he can aye sit down an' rest He can beg for his dinner, he has nothin' else to do Only toddle around the corner with his old rigadoo

verse.name: v2
verse.lines: Well, I slept in a barn way down by Killavone On a dark and stormy night and sleepin' all alone With holes in the roof and the rain a-comin' through And the rats and the mice they were playin' peek-a-boo

verse.name: v3
verse.lines: O, then, who did waken but the woman of the house With her white spotty apron and her calico blouse She began to cry and when I said: Boo O, now, don't you be afraid o' me, it's only Johnny Dhu

verse.name: v4
verse.lines: Well, I met a little flaxen-haired girl the other day Good morning to you, flaxen-haired girl, I did say Good morning, Johnny Beggarman, there's how do ye do? With your rags and your bags and your old rigadoo

verse.name: v5
verse.lines: Well, I'll buy ye a pair o' trousers, a collar and a tie And a nice little lassie then I'll fetch her by an' by I'll buy a pair of goggles, and I'll paint them up so blue And that nice little lassie, I'll be her lover, too

verse.name: v6
verse.lines: Well, it's over the road, wi' me bag upon me back It's over the fields wi' me big haver-sack With holes in me shoes and me toes peepin' through Singing: Tithery-ump-a-daddy, sure, I'm old Johnny Dhu

verse.name: v7
verse.lines: So now my song is ended and I'll bid you's all good night The fires are all raked and it's out with the light And now you've heard the story of the old rigadoo It's good luck and God be wid you's and to old Johnny, too
